questions.neutral: You made it in one piece?

hobby.message: Any new mods on your FPV quad?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Yeah. Been out exploring a bit. Urban hobby, nothing special.
Can't say it's easy lately.
Security’s been odd since the testimony mess.
Let’s just say some tunnels aren’t as quiet as before.
Yeah, made it. Spent some hours poking around utility tunnels.
Urban exploration’s my thing. Better than the crowded lifts upstairs.
Even that’s tricky now—systems get touchy after all this ghost fuss.
Last night, had a door freeze on me. Not normal.
Makes you rethink how visible you want to be.
Survived, somehow. Was out exploring the old fiber ducts below eastern loop.
Urban exploration keeps me sane—find the old tech no one remembers.
Usually it's just rats and broken nodes. Lately, bumped into new faces.
After those ghost confessions, places feel less abandoned than usual.
Ran into a crew rerouting live lines—never used to see that.
Whole access rules are a mess now. Bit more fun, honestly.
Yeah, good to see a living face. Spent half the night in a substation tunnel.
Urban exploration. Not just crawling, I map and fix leftover circuitry if I spot trouble.
Was hoping for peace, but the system glitches since the ghosts testified.
Met a few ex-state techs. Nobody logs in properly these days, too risky.
We traded routes and stories over some liquor. Small tribe under the city now.
Old BCI rules are unreliable, so we chalked our own markers.
Strange bonus: less oversight means we actually fix things.
Just got in, still smelling like conduit dust. Hit the bar after long tunnel shift.
Urban exploration’s more than habit—spent decades mapping forgotten utility spaces.
Started in the old grid collapse, still chasing hidden circuits the city left behind.
Recent ghost leaks upended everything. Doors ignore scores, random crews show up off-grid.
Ran into some erased folks, swapped tips. It’s wild—official logs act like they don’t exist.
Saw patched fiber routed through ‘vanished’ nodes. Proof city systems are more lost than we realized.
We swapped a bottle, chalked our own access codes, old-school style.
Feels risky, but this mess finally makes urban exploring worthwhile again.
hobby_answer: Not boring, no. Always something new underground.
Most spots locked since the BCI leak anyway.
Now with all the ghosts back, no point going where I’m not wanted.
Security tightens every week. Makes things bland.
Usually just keep to myself, since things got noisy.
Never boring. Too much changes too fast, lately.
Half the city’s tunnels got new locks after the data dump.
Ghost sightings push patrols into places nobody bothered before.
Most nights I just walk, not fix—no tools, just a look.
Clients call less. Don’t want to risk being flagged.
We all stay quick on our feet now.
Never boring—city never sits still, especially these days.
Ghosts reappearing turned the regular routes upside down.
Hardly anyone trusts the BCI since the leaks.
I miss when I could do long stretches without tripping an alert.
Ran into a few others, same story: we trade notes now.
Feels different wandering when everyone’s paranoid.
Still, the tunnels breathe better with less oversight.
Boring? Not once. The old tunnels always have stories.
With ghosts showing up again, it's a whole new map down there.
Security’s lost the plot—access points blink at the wrong scores now.
Crossed paths with an old crew, none of us listed anywhere official.
We worked blind, no system oversight—felt more alive than usual.
Used to dodge cameras, now cameras don't even see me half the time.
People in the tunnels are friendly, unless they're Directorate.
Late nights, we chalk up new paths that the system can't erase.
Never dull. I started poking at ducts for peace, stayed for the chaos.
After Halden died, patterns broke—sensors lag, doors glitch, routines fail.
Those ‘ghost’ testimonies made the tunnels busy again—old faces resurfacing, half-digital, half-myth.
Now, I can slip through blocks off-limits for months. Feels strange.
Ran into folks who used to be erased—taught me their quiet ways.
Council chokes on control, doesn’t get that adaptation always wins.
Sharing homemade hooch with others under the market—nobody cares about scores there.
It’s fun again: like slipping past grown-ups at curfew.
A city’s heart isn’t its order, it’s the sound under the grid.
